The major factor that affects VMCG is the difference in engine thrust

learning.explanation: In simple words, VMCG is established as being the lowest speed at which rudder effect alone is sufficient to regain and maintain directional control after a sudden engine failure. The major factor that affects VMCG is the difference in engine thrust. VMCG will therefore be lower at higher airport elevations and at a higher OAT, due to the associated lower thrust. Conversely, VMCG will be higher at lower airport elevations and at a lower OAT. If conditions are hot, high and humid the air is less dense. This reduces thrust and, consequently, when you lose the critical engine on take-off, there is less yawing effect from asymmetric thrust than there would be in denser air.

content.question: During a take-off roll with a strong crosswind from the right, a four-engine jet aeroplane with wing-mounted engines experiences an engine failure. The failure of which engine will cause the greatest control problem?

options.A: The right outboard engine.
options.C: The left outboard engine.

key_points: During a crosswind take-off, an airplane tends to weathercock into wind (yaw into the wind), due to the wind acting on the fin which produces a yaw moment
In this case, with a crosswind from the right, the aircraft will tend to yaw right
If a left engine fails, the right side will produce much more thrust than the left side, resulting in a left-yaw
learning.explanation: During a crosswind take-off, an airplane tends to weathercock into wind (yaw into the wind), due to the wind acting on the fin which produces a yaw moment. In this case, with a crosswind from the right, the aircraft will tend to yaw right. If a left engine fails, the right side will produce much more thrust than the left side, resulting in a left-yaw. This will oppose the yaw-right moment. If a right engine fails, the left side will produce more thrust than the right side, resulting in a right-yaw. This will add to the right-yaw moment. The engine's distance to the CG is greatest for outboard engines, which means that they have the largest moment arms. The loss of an outboard engine will result in the strongest yaw tendency. Therefore, the failure of the outboard engine on the windward side of the airplane is the most difficult to counteract.

the nose will drop and

Banking towards the live engine also reduces the side force on the fin from sideslip, which minimizes VMC, effectively reduces the yawing moment and gives more rudder authority to stop the yaw. content.question: Following de-icing on a foggy morning, a pilot has to apply more thrust than expected during the take-off roll. Which of the following could have caused this?

options.A: A higher angle of attack due to the higher speed in icing conditions.
options.B: Ice build-up remaining on the fuselage means that the aircraft is heavier than expected.
options.C: Increased fuel density due to low temperatures.
options.D: Reduced air density due to low temperatures.

key_points: Ice build-up on an airframe: Increases drag - By significantly disturbing the shape of the airframe, parasite drag is increased
Decreases lift - By disturbing the shape of the wings, ice can cause a large reduction in lift
Increase Weight - Ice build-up can be quite significant, and water is a naturally heavy substance, so lots of weight can be added by the presence of ice
learning.explanation: Ice build-up on an airframe: Increases drag - By significantly disturbing the shape of the airframe, parasite drag is increased. Decreases lift - By disturbing the shape of the wings, ice can cause a large reduction in lift. Increase Weight - Ice build-up can be quite significant, and water is a naturally heavy substance, so lots of weight can be added by the presence of ice. During de-icing on the ground, the fuselage does not always need to be de-iced. Frost or thin layers of ice are usually acceptable to leave on the fuselage, as long as it is not deemed a critical area, such as the wings, control surfaces, engine inlets, propellers, etc. (aircraft with rear mounted engines often have to de-ice the whole fuselage to stop ice shedding off into the engines). This build-up could allow extra weight to be carried in the form of ice or frost during the take-off roll. Whilst it is hoped that only a small amount of ice/frost would be carried, on a large fuselage, that could amount to quite a large weight that is unaccounted for and unknown in value. This could be felt by the pilot as a lack of thrust due to the lower acceleration, and they might have to apply more thrust to account for this. To address the other options: "A higher angle of attack due to the higher speed in icing conditions." Higher speed would cause a lower angle of attack, so this is not correct. "Ice build-up remaining on the fuselage means you are heavier than expected." As discussed above, whilst this should be kept to a minimum, it is possible for this to be the case. "Increased fuel density due to low temperatures." Yes, low temperatures will cause higher fuel density, but large aircraft are fuelled up by mass, and not by volume, so this will just mean that the fuel uses up less of the tank volume than it would in warmer conditions. "Reduced air density due to low temperatures." Low temperatures cause high air density, which would feel like more power than usual.

content.question: While going around in an airport with temperature at negative 10 degrees, a light twin-engine aircraft with normally-aspirated piston engines experiences an engine failure. How will the environment described affect VMCA?

options.A: Decreased effectiveness of controls due to low air temperature will increase VMCA.
options.B: Increased effectiveness of controls due to high air density will decrease VMCA.
options.C: High engine performance on the operating engine due to high air density will decrease VMCA.
options.D: High engine performance on the operating engine due to high air density will increase VMCA.

key_points: The approach speed of a light twin engine aircraft is usually 1
3 times the stall speed, which is an indicated airspeed
Temperature (and the resulting density) is usually not a factor (when the temperature is within the operational limits) in determining the approach speed
learning.explanation: The approach speed of a light twin engine aircraft is usually 1.3 times the stall speed, which is an indicated airspeed. Temperature (and the resulting density) is usually not a factor (when the temperature is within the operational limits) in determining the approach speed. With the same approach speed (in IAS) the effectiveness of control will be the same before and upon the initiation of go around. The difference is that in a low temperature (higher density) environment a normally aspirated piston engine will produce a higher power output (with a higher manifold pressure) when compared with a high temperature (lower density) situation during go around in full throttle. Therefore, with more power output at the engines during go around it becomes harder to counteract in an engine failure situation – which leads to an increased demand in the effectiveness of control during engine failure. That demand in higher control effectiveness will be achieved by flying faster – hence an increase in VMCA.

content.question: If a pilot initiates a level, co-ordinated turn from straight and level flight at the same altitude and does not change thrust, the speed will:

options.A: increase and the aeroplane will eventually stall.
options.C: decrease.

key_points: The basic four forces that act on an aircraft are thrust, drag, lift and weight
If one of these forces changes, the opposite force shall have to change to have the same effect as before the change
In this question we want to stay in level flight at the same altitude and thrust will not be changed
learning.explanation: The basic four forces that act on an aircraft are thrust, drag, lift and weight. If one of these forces changes, the opposite force shall have to change to have the same effect as before the change. In this question we want to stay in level flight at the same altitude and thrust will not be changed. We will go from a situation where the plane is going straight forward, to a situation where the plane is banked. To understand this, we will have to understand the way lift works on the aircraft. The lift vector goes directly vertical from the aircraft’s fuselage. This means that if the aircraft flies straight, the lift vector points directly upwards. If the aircraft banks to the right, the lift vector will move diagonally towards the right as well, creating a smaller upwards vector together with a vector towards the right, which creates the yaw moment resulting in the right turn. If we look at the lift formula (CL * ½ * ρ * V^2 * S), we see that the lift coëfficiënt and speed are directly related. In case of the banked aircraft, the upwards vector (vertical lift) decreased. To remain at the same altitude, we must pitch up (increase in CL). With a constant thrust position, speed will therefore decrease.

content.question: A twin engine aircraft is in the cruise when both of its engines fail simultaneously. The pilot deploys full flaps almost immediately. Was this the correct decision?

options.A: Yes, because the flaps increase lift, and therefore increase the glide range.
options.B: Yes, because the flaps will allow the aircraft to glide for a longer duration.
options.C: No, because the L/D ratio decreases and ROD increases.
options.D: No, because the flaps will interfere with any attempt to restart the engines.

key_points: Flaps are very useful on aircraft for decreasing the stall speed, allowing aircraft to safely land and take-off at much lower speeds than they would with a clean wing
This has numerous benefits, including the shortening of runways
Flaps have very limited uses in flight, though, and there is a good reason why pilots are so hasty to get rid of them after take-off
learning.explanation: Flaps are very useful on aircraft for decreasing the stall speed, allowing aircraft to safely land and take-off at much lower speeds than they would with a clean wing. This has numerous benefits, including the shortening of runways. Flaps have very limited uses in flight, though, and there is a good reason why pilots are so hasty to get rid of them after take-off. Flaps increase the drag of a wing, reducing climb rates and increasing fuel burn. The use of flaps in a glide descent increases the drag for no real increase in lift (flaps can increase lift, but the aircraft has not got any heavier, so does not need it), and therefore drastically reduce the L/D ratio (Lift to Drag ratio). The L/D ratio is what decides the glide angle, and flaps cause a steeper glide angle, leading to a greater rate of descent. The pilot therefore made a very poor decision, and has drastically decreased their available glide distance and glide endurance. Usually, if gliding to a forced landing, the pilot will remain in a clean configuration as long as possible, until landing is assured, then can extend flaps as required to slow down sufficiently and make a slower landing.

learning.explanation: ENGINE FAILURE If one engine on a conventional twin-engine aircraft fails in flight, it adversely affects its performance and controllability. If one engine fails in flight, the remaining thrust forces are asymmetrically displaced and the aircraft yaws in the direction of the failed engine. YAWING MOMENT The yawing moment is the product of thrust from the operating engine multiplied by the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm), plus the drag from the failed engine multiplied by the distance between the engine centre line and the CG. The strength of the yawing moment will depend on: - how much thrust the operating engine is developing (throttle setting and density altitude). - the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm). - how much drag is being produced by the failed engine. This effect will be absent on an aircraft with counter-rotating propellers, contra-rotating propellers or jet engines. RUDDER MOMENT The rudder moment, which balances the yawing moment, is the result of the rudder force multiplied by the distance between the fin CP and the CG (rudder arm) The ability of the pilot to counteract the yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust will depend on: - rudder displacement (affecting rudder force). - CG position (affecting rudder arm). - the IAS (affecting rudder force).

learning.explanation: A coordinated turn is a turn where there is no sideslip or skid, this is the most effective and therefore preferable way to turn. In a coordinated turn, the turn and bank indicator in the plane shows the ball in the center. If the turn is not coordinated, you’re either in a slip or a skid. These two things are different and shall therefore be eliminated differently. A slipping turn is a turn where the aircraft’s nose is outside of the turning radius and the tail is in the turn radius. A slip is caused by using too much bank and too little rudder. A skidding turn is a turn where the aircraft’s nose is inside of the turning radius and the tail is outside of the turn radius. A skid is caused by using too much rudder and not enough bank. The indicator works via the “step on the ball” principle. If the ball is right of center, you should give (more) right rudder and vice versa.

content.question: A light aircraft has a lift to drag ratio of 25 (L / D = 25). What is the maximum gliding distance from a height of 1000 m?

key_points: LIFT/DRAG RATIO An appreciation of the efficiency of lift production is gained from studying the ratio between lift and drag, a high L/D ratio being more efficient
For maximum efficiency, the wings should produce maximum lift with the least possible drag
The L/D ratio increases with angle of attack up to a maximum at about 4°; this is called the “optimum” angle of attack
learning.explanation: LIFT/DRAG RATIO An appreciation of the efficiency of lift production is gained from studying the ratio between lift and drag, a high L/D ratio being more efficient. For maximum efficiency, the wings should produce maximum lift with the least possible drag. The L/D ratio increases with angle of attack up to a maximum at about 4°; this is called the “optimum” angle of attack. The L/D ratio then decreases with increasing angle of attack until CLMAX is reached. ANGLE OF DESCENT IN THE GLIDE Glide angle is a function ONLY of the L/D ratio. The descent (glide) angle will be least when the L/D ratio is the greatest. L/D ratio is a maximum at the optimum angle of attack, and this also corresponds to the minimum drag speed (VMD). At speeds above or below VMD the glide angle will be steeper. Maximum distance in a glide can be achieved when the aircraft is flown at (L/D)MAX (VMD). EFFECT OF WIND The glide angle will determine the distance that the aircraft can glide for a given change of height. GLIDE DISTANCE = HEIGHT LOSS × (LIFT / DRAG) This distance would only be achieved in still air. If there is a wind, the ground speed will change, and so the distance over the ground will change. In a headwind the ground distance will be decreased, and in a tailwind it will be increased. In this question, using the above formula, where: Height Loss = 1000m Lift/Drag = 25 GLIDE DISTANCE = HEIGHT LOSS × (LIFT / DRAG) = 1000 x 25 = 25000m GLIDE DISTANCE = 25000m.

content.question: Compare an aircraft with the engines mounted under the wing with one where the engines are mounted above the wing. For an aircraft with engines mounted under the wing, the (1) _____ force from the tailplane will be (2) _____.

options.A: (1) downwards; (2) greater
options.C: (1) upwards; (2) smaller

key_points: This question is about force/moment couples

In a conventional aeroplane, the Lift opposes the Weight and the Thrust opposes the Drag, however, the Lift is produced from the Centre of Pressure (CP), and the Weight is produced from the Centre of Gravity (CG)
The CG is ahead of the CP, so that "force couple" produces a nose down moment on the aircraft
learning.explanation: This question is about force/moment couples. In a conventional aeroplane, the Lift opposes the Weight and the Thrust opposes the Drag, however, the Lift is produced from the Centre of Pressure (CP), and the Weight is produced from the Centre of Gravity (CG). The CG is ahead of the CP, so that "force couple" produces a nose down moment on the aircraft. Thrust and Drag have a similar relationship. Thrust is produced through the thrust line of the engines, and Drag is produced from the Centre of Pressure, and therefore if the engines are mounted low down (underslung), this "force couple" will provide a nose up moment, but if they are mounted high up, above the wings, then this "force couple" may produce a nose down moment instead. The tailplane (horizontal stabiliser) is present, not only to provide a place to mount the elevator control surfaces, but also as a way to balance out the force couples through the aircraft with a pitch trim system. Tailplanes usually provide downforce on a conventional aeroplane in order to provide a tail-down, nose-up balancing moment, and that is what the examiner is talking about here, so even though sometimes tailplanes can provide upwards lift, it is much rarer. The downforce produced by tailplanes is undesirable as it assists gravity in pulling the aircraft downwards, meaning that the main wing has to produce more lift to counteract this, increasing the stall speed and, more importantly, increasing drag. A few ways to reduce this downforce are to change the force couples mentioned above. The CG can be moved aft to reduce the Lift/Weight couple, so the aircraft doesn't need as much nose-up moment, and therefore the tail can produce less downforce. Another factor is the engine placement, and the lower the engines are mounted, the greater the nose-up moment from the Thrust/Drag couple becomes, and the LESS downforce that is required from the tailplane. We are aware that, if the tailplane is providing an upwards force already with high mounted engines, that this upwards force will increase for low mounted engines, however this would not be a conventional aeroplane at that point, so is not what the examiner is talking about, which removes the potential of two correct answers.

In the event of an engine failure in a non-centerline thrust twin or multi engine aircraft, the operative engine is going to create a strong yawing moment about the vertical axis of the aircraft in the direction of the dead engine

Uncorrected, this results in a forward slip toward the side of the good engine and, when combined with the fuselage blanking airflow over the wing on the dead engine side, a rolling moment also develops about the longitudinal axis in the direction of the dead engine
learning.explanation: COUNTERACTING ASYMMETRIC THRUST Rudder to Stop Yaw - Bank Towards Live Engine - This method produces minimum drag and gives the best ability to climb and is the preferred method of putting the aircraft in equilibrium following engine failure. In the event of an engine failure in a non-centerline thrust twin or multi engine aircraft, the operative engine is going to create a strong yawing moment about the vertical axis of the aircraft in the direction of the dead engine. Uncorrected, this results in a forward slip toward the side of the good engine and, when combined with the fuselage blanking airflow over the wing on the dead engine side, a rolling moment also develops about the longitudinal axis in the direction of the dead engine. The typical action is to apply rudder in the direction of the live engine to counteract this forward slip. However, while the nose will be aligned with the desired flight path doing this, the actual flight path is a side slip towards the dead engine side, which creates excess drag. The only available counter to this is to bank the airplane into the direction of the live engine to counteract the rudder force using the horizontal component of lift. The angle of bank must not exceed 5°, to prevent excessive loss of vertical lift component.

options.C: MMO

The most correct answer we believe is best range, but please let us know in the comments if you see this question in an exam, and any information you have about it, as our feedback may not be complete
Alternatively, feedback can be sent to info@atplquestions
learning.explanation: Note: This question does not have a lot of information, and in fact none of the answers are what we would consider to be fully correct. The most correct answer we believe is best range, but please let us know in the comments if you see this question in an exam, and any information you have about it, as our feedback may not be complete. Alternatively, feedback can be sent to info@atplquestions.com, thank you. We are also under the impression that this has been seen in Principles of Flight, but believe it to be more of a Performance question, so let us know which exam you see this in, thanks. In the event of a fuel leak, our main problem as a flight crew is the chance of fuel exhaustion before a safe landing has been made. It is for that reason that we must make our way to the nearest suitable airfield as fast as possible, but by using the least amount of fuel; after all, we do not want to run out of fuel faster than we have to, by using it or by leaking it. It is for this reason that we have to fly at the best range speed, the same as we would when we want to reach a destination whilst using as little fuel as possible. However, this is a different "best range" speed. When we are leaking out fuel, our total fuel "consumption" changes, and goes from the standard fuel consumption/speed curve (which closely follows the drag curve), to the same curve, just lifted up, as the fuel consumption has been increased across the board by whatever rate the fuel is leaking at. Of course, the leak could be variable with speed or pressure, etc. but this is the general idea of it, and we should not have to delve as far as those factors. The best range of an aircraft is the point at which the fuel consumption is lowest for the highest speed, and this is shown on the graph by the point where a line from the origin first touches the curve. As you can see in the annex above, the best range speed is higher for the curve with the fuel leak. This is because the fuel is also leaking from the tank, and the faster we go, the less we allow to leak from the tank overall, so the more we have available to burn. This finds an equilibrium with how much drag we are willing to accept by flying faster, and therefore burning fuel at a higher rate. The faster the fuel leak, the higher this optimal speed becomes, starting at the normal "Best Range" speed for a very small/no leak, and increasing to VMO for incredibly fast fuel leaks. Further note: We would prefer an answer that mentions something to do with the increased best range speed, or perhaps a speed between best range speed and VMO.

Given:
Aeroplane mass: 50000 kg.
Lift/Drag ratio: 12.
Thrust per engine: 21000 N.
Assumed g: 10 m/s².
For a straight, steady, wings level climb of a four-engine aeroplane, the all-engines climb gradient is:

key_points: Consider an aircraft in a straight steady climb along a straight flight path inclined at an angle (γ) to the horizontal
γ (gamma) is the symbol used for climb angle
The forces on the aircraft consist of Lift, normal to the flight path; Thrust and Drag, parallel to it; and Weight, parallel to the force of gravity
learning.explanation: Consider an aircraft in a straight steady climb along a straight flight path inclined at an angle (γ) to the horizontal. γ (gamma) is the symbol used for climb angle. The forces on the aircraft consist of Lift, normal to the flight path; Thrust and Drag, parallel to it; and Weight, parallel to the force of gravity. Weight is resolved into two components: one opposite Lift (W cos γ) and the other acting in the same direction as Drag (W sin γ), backwards along the flight path. The requirements for equilibrium are: Thrust must equal the sum of Drag plus the backwards component of Weight; and Lift must equal its opposing component of Weight. For equilibrium at a greater angle of climb, the Lift required will be less, and the backwards component of Weight will be greater. L = W cosγ T = D + W sinγ In a straight steady climb, Lift is less than Weight because Lift only has to support a proportion of the weight, this proportion decreasing as the climb angle increases. The remaining proportion of Weight is supported by engine Thrust. It can be seen that for a straight steady climb the Thrust required is greater than Drag. This is to balance the backward component of Weight acting along the flight path. The climb gradient can be described as: sin γ = (T−D)/W For very shallow flight path angles (γ), we can assume that lift is approximately equal to Weight, therefore the climb gradient can be described as: sin γ = (T/W)−(D/L) In this exercise, Weight is equal to 500000N, D/L ratio is equal to 1/12 and Thrust equal to 21000N per engine. For the all engines (four) climb gradient and applying the formula defined above: sin γ = (84000/500000)−(1/12) sin γ = 0.085 ⇒ sinγ = 8.5% The climb gradient is 8.5%.

content.question: In a co-ordinated horizontal turn, the magnitude of the centripetal force at 45 degrees of bank:

options.A: is equal to the lift of the aeroplane.
options.C: is equal to the weight of the aeroplane.
options.D: is greater than the lift of the aeroplane.

key_points: In level flight, any turn will be coordinated or uncoordinated

A coordinated turn is one in which the only acceleration is along the normal axis of the airplane, towards the center of the turn, and the angle of bank is precisely correct for the aircraft speed and the radius of turn
If not all these factors are present, the turn will be uncoordinated and there will be a lateral acceleration either towards or away from the center of the turn
learning.explanation: In level flight, any turn will be coordinated or uncoordinated. A coordinated turn is one in which the only acceleration is along the normal axis of the airplane, towards the center of the turn, and the angle of bank is precisely correct for the aircraft speed and the radius of turn. If not all these factors are present, the turn will be uncoordinated and there will be a lateral acceleration either towards or away from the center of the turn. The total lift of a balanced turn provides the centripetal force and the force that opposes the mass of the airplane. If there is acceleration towards the center of the turn the airplane is slipping and if it is away from the center of the turn the airplane is skidding. Either condition will be indicated on the turn and slip indicator. An overbanked airplane will slip into the turn and requires an increase of speed or a reduction in bank angle to correct this condition. An underbanked airplane will skid out of the turn, which requires a decreased speed or an increased bank angle to correct this condition. These are indicated on the turn and slip indicator by the needle one-way and the ball the other. To maintain altitude and airspeed when executing a turn both the angle of attack and the thrust have to be increased above their level flight values. In a turn, the centripetal force is defined as: CF = L * sinΦ And Weight is defined by: W = L * cosΦ Dividing one by the other, we get: (L∗ sinΦ)/(L∗ cosΦ) = CF/W Then: tanΦ = CF/W W * tanΦ = CF For a 45° bank angle where tan 45° = 1, CF = W.

content.question: An aircraft with a mass of 60 tons is performing a co-ordinated level turn with 60º angle of bank. What is the magnitude of the Centripetal Force?

key_points: During a steady, co-ordinated turn, at a constant altitude, a force must continually act toward the centre of the turn (centripetal force)
If it is not present, the aircraft will be unable to maintain a curved path, but instead will fly off at a tangent
When the aircraft banks, the total lift force tilts; the horizontal component of lift provides the centripetal force and the vertical component of lift supports the weight of the aircraft
learning.explanation: During a steady, co-ordinated turn, at a constant altitude, a force must continually act toward the centre of the turn (centripetal force). If it is not present, the aircraft will be unable to maintain a curved path, but instead will fly off at a tangent. When the aircraft banks, the total lift force tilts; the horizontal component of lift provides the centripetal force and the vertical component of lift supports the weight of the aircraft. There are a few ways to calculate the centripetal force. You can use the formula -- Centripetal force = Lift x sin(bank angle) -- but this would require some extra steps in this question, as the lift is not equal to weight, during the banked turn. You can certainly work out the lift from the formula -- Lift = Weight / cos(bank angle) -- if you like, and this will work fine, followed by the formula above to work out the centripetal force. Instead, using basic trigonometry, we can work out that the weight and the centripetal force are linked by the tan function, and the following formula exists (There is a formula derivation in the explanation of question 819095 if you are interested but you do not need to know it for the exams, just remember the formula). Centripetal force = Weight x tan(bank angle) Before we can make the calculation, we must first calculate the weight from the mass, using the formula -- Weight = Mass x acceleration due to gravity (g) The acceleration due to gravity is a value of 9.81 m/s2 on the Earth's surface (sometimes questions will ask you to use 10 m/s2 for this). Weight = 60 000 x 9.81 = 588 600 N Using the above formula, Centripetal force = 588 600 x tan(60) = 1 019 485 N

As a consequence, the outer wing will rise and the inner wing will fall. WING DIHEDRAL AND RUDDER INPUT IN A TURN Wing dihedral is very powerful in producing lateral stability. Dihedral effect is used to discribe the lateral stability contribution of other airplane components, such as rudder and sweptback wings. Rudder input produces sideslip and contributes to the dihedral effect. The effect is proportional to the angle of sideslip - roll increases with sideslip angle and, therefore, roll increases with increasing rudder input. The rudders on transport airplanes are sized to counter the yawing moment associated with an engine failure at very low takeoff speeds and to conduct crosswind takeoffs and landings, using up to maximum pedal input. Any excessive rudder input can produce a large sideslip angle, which will generate a rolling moment that requires significant lateral control input to stop the airplane from rolling. The rudder should not normally be used to induce roll through sideslip because it has the potential to induce rapid roll rates with significant time delays from the initial input. This overreaction can induce abrupt yawing moments and violent out-of-phase roll rates, which can lead to successive cyclic rudder deflections, known as rudder reversals as the pilot tries to control the resulting motions. Large aggressive control reversals induce loads that can exceed structural design limits. Except in crosswind takeoff and landing, keeping the sideslip as close to zero as possible will ensure that the maximum amount of lateral control is available for maneuvering. Rudder should only be used in combination with ailerons/spoilers to eliminate sideslip, not create it.

The aircraft does not know what the wind component is, it will glide exactly the same, wind or no wind. The only difference will be where it ends up. Therefore the rate of descent in the glide will be exactly the same, and the time to descend will be exactly the same. key_points: A coordinated turn is when no sideslip occurs on the aircraft

learning.explanation: A coordinated turn is when no sideslip occurs on the aircraft. An uncoordinated turn can either be a slipping turn or a skidding turn. Those that know cars will be able to think of this similar to understeer (slipping turn) and oversteer (skidding turn). Slipping turns occur when ailerons are used to turn without enough rudder, so for example a left turn without using any left rudder. The aircraft rolls left and starts sideslipping to the left but the body does not actually rotate in that direction as fast as the turn occurs, and the aircraft "slips" or "falls" into the turn. This looks a bit like understeer in a car. Skidding turns are more like drifting a car (oversteer). Too much rudder has been used in the direction of turn, with not enough ailerons, so the bank angle is not steep enough to fly in a coordinated manner. A skidding turn to the left means that the aircraft would be pointing into the turn too much, sideslipping to the right. A skidding turn can be fixed by reducing the rudder input (or applying opposite rudder) or by rolling further into the turn, as extra bank angle can also coordinate the turn (if no extra rudder is used). Airspeed is a bit more complex in this scenario, and we don't believe that it is within the current learning objectives to ask such a question, but if you look creatively at the LOs and combine them with a bit of extra mental stretching, then we can slightly see what the examiner might be trying to test. They are getting at the fact that at higher airspeeds, to get the same rate of turn, the aircraft needs a greater angle of bank. So therefore, for the turn in the question, if we have too little bank angle, that could also mean that we have the correct bank angle for that rate of turn, but we're just going too fast, and THAT is the reason our turn is a skidding turn. Imagine we use the bank angle to do a coordinated rate 1 turn (3 degrees per second) to the left at 70 kts, but we are doing 110 kts instead. Not enough bank angle would be used to get 3 degrees per second, and that left rudder input to make us turn at 3 degrees per second would make the turn uncoordinated (skidding) at that higher speed. It is difficult to imagine, as it is a completely ridiculous scenario. Of course, in reality we would just fly a coordinated turn at 110 kts, realise that the bank angle isn't giving us 3 degrees per second, and increase it, but the examiner is trying - quite poorly - to combine more than one learning objective here. Therefore, we are saying that a skidding turn can be caused by having INSUFFICIENT bank angle and/or TOO MUCH airspeed.

content.question: A single engine aeroplane flying at 3 000 ft suffers an engine failure. With a lift to drag ratio of 16:1, a TAS of 90 kt and a 10 kt headwind, how far can the aircraft glide?

key_points: Glide angle (and glide range) assumes no thrust, and therefore is determined directly by the lift over drag (L/D) ratio
The best L/D ratio occurs at VMD, the speed for minimum drag
Glide angle = CD / CL GLIDING DISTANCE Wind speed is an important practical influence on gliding distance over the surface
learning.explanation: Glide angle (and glide range) assumes no thrust, and therefore is determined directly by the lift over drag (L/D) ratio. The best L/D ratio occurs at VMD, the speed for minimum drag. Glide angle = CD / CL GLIDING DISTANCE Wind speed is an important practical influence on gliding distance over the surface. With a tailwind, the glide distance achieved will be increased as a result of the increased groundspeed. Whereas with a headwind, it will be reduced because of the consequently slower groundspeed. There are two ways to calculate this question. METHOD 1 With a L/D ratio of 16:1, this means the glide ratio is 16:1 (horizontal distance : vertical distance). Therefore, at a TAS of 90 kt, the vertical speed is 90/16 = 5.625 kt 5.625 kt = 5.625nm per hour. Multiply by 6080 to get feet per hour, then divide by 60 to get feet per minute, giving 570 fpm rate of descent. The aircraft will take a time of 3 000 / 570 = 5.263 minutes to descend 3 000 ft. 5.263 minutes (divide by 60) is 0.0877 hours. Multiply this by the groundspeed this time (90 - 10 = 80 kt) to get the distance travelled over the ground in that time. 0.0877 x 80 = 7.016 nm, closest answer 7.02 nm METHOD 2 3 000 ft to descend at glide ratio of 16:1 means that the horizontal distance travelled is 3 000 x 16 = 48 000 ft. Divide this by 6080 ft/nm to get a still air ground distance of 7.895 nm. With a headwind, this distance is reduced slightly (already the correct answer can likely be guessed). The reduction is the headwind as a proportion of the TAS, so the distance is reduced by 10kt/90kt = 0.111., or in other words, the new distance is 88.9% of the still air distance. 7.89 x 0.889 = 7.018 nm, closest answer 7.02 nm. This second way is faster if you are comfortable with visualising it like this, especially as the correct answer can be identified quite early on with gross error checking, but if in doubt, use METHOD 1.

learning.explanation: This question is asking about stable asymmetric flight with wings level. This is one of the standard methods for flying with a failed engine, and the other method is to fly with a small bank angle towards the live engine (five to the live). When we fly in stable (heading not changing) asymmetric flight, there is a complex combination of forces on the aircraft. If a force does not act directly through the aircraft's centre of gravity, then it also creates a moment (turning force). To be in equilibrium (heading and speed not changing), the aircraft's forces and moments must all match up and be equal. See the annex above, the top half shows us what we need to see for this question, the wings level scenario. Assuming the right engine fails, the left engine is producing a clockwise moment (viewed from above). The rudder has to be deflected to the left to produce a right-wards side force on the aircraft tail (a force away from the live engine), this anticlockwise moment evens out the thrust asymmetry moment, except now we are not longer flying straight, we are sideslipping to the right. The combination of forwards thrust and rightwards force mean we have the relative airflow hitting us from the right-hand side. This causes another force. The extra force can have different names, but this question calls it the fuselage side force. It imagines the fuselage is a wing, and the air coming from the side is creating an angle of attack, creating a sidewards lifting effect, off to the left side, opposite to the rudder force direction. This is fine, but we have to consider what moment it might produce. If it were just the fuselage to consider, then the lifting force would happen in front of the CG, but due to other features (mainly the large tail fin), the total force acts from behind the CG. In this way, it is an opposing moment to the rudder (it is acting with the thrust asymmetry), and means the required rudder force is higher. The diagram calls it the "weathercocking yawing moment". It happens because of sideslip; ballistic skid appears to be a made-up phrase. Looking at the bottom half of the annex, you can see that the small bank angle to the live engine makes the sideslip go away and can reduce the complexity of the scenario greatly, and reduce drag.

ENGINE FAILURE If one engine on a conventional twin-engine aircraft fails in flight, it adversely affects its performance and controllability. With both engines operating at the same power setting on a twin-engine aircraft, the amount of thrust produced by each engine is identical and their lines of action are symmetrically displaced about the aircraft's normal axis. If one engine fails in flight, the remaining thrust forces are asymmetrically displaced and the aircraft yaws in the direction of the failed engine. YAWING MOMENT The yawing moment is the product of thrust from the operating engine multiplied by the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm), (plus the drag from the failed engine multiplied by the distance between the engine centre line and the CG). The strength of the yawing moment will depend on: - how much thrust the operating engine is developing (throttle setting and density altitude). - the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm). - how much drag is being produced by the failed engine. The rudder moment, which balances the yawing moment, is the result of the rudder force multiplied by the distance between the fin CP and the CG (rudder arm) The ability of the pilot to counteract the yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust will depend on: - rudder displacement (affecting rudder force). - CG position (affecting rudder moment arm). - the IAS (affecting rudder force). This question is asking us which scenario is worst for controllability, which is where there is a high yawing moment, and our rudder has a low balancing moment. This would be at low altitude, high thrust settings, and low airspeed. This is because the high thrust creates a large asymmetry, and there is not much airflow over the rudder to fight against it. A further decrease in controllability comes when the aircraft is at a low weight. The pilot can use a small bank angle onto the side of the live engine to reduce the aircraft's sideslip, and therefore its rudder deflection. This "banking technique" uses the aircraft's weight, and a heavier aircraft (counter-intuitively) is actually better for controllability. Therefore, the worst scenario here is during a go-around with an empty aircraft.

learning.explanation: The failure of one engine leads to asymmetric thrust and drag, causing the aircraft to yaw towards the failed engine. This yaw can be corrected using the rudder, which must counteract the asymmetric forces. To reduce the rudder workload and mitigate the risk of fin stall, a slight bank towards the live engine, typically limited to 5 degrees, can be employed. This small bank angle generates a lateral lift component that offsets the lateral rudder force, reducing or eliminating the sideslip. Regulations impose a 5-degree limit on bank angles for this maneuver. Beyond this limit, increased lift is required, resulting in higher induced drag. key_points: ENGINE FAILURE If one engine on a conventional twin-engine aircraft fails in flight, it adversely affects its performance and controllability

With both engines operating at the same power setting on a twin-engine aircraft, the amount of thrust produced by each engine is identical and their lines of action are symmetrically displaced about the aircraft's normal axis
If one engine fails in flight, the remaining thrust forces are asymmetrically displaced and the aircraft yaws in the direction of the failed engine
learning.explanation: ENGINE FAILURE If one engine on a conventional twin-engine aircraft fails in flight, it adversely affects its performance and controllability. With both engines operating at the same power setting on a twin-engine aircraft, the amount of thrust produced by each engine is identical and their lines of action are symmetrically displaced about the aircraft's normal axis. If one engine fails in flight, the remaining thrust forces are asymmetrically displaced and the aircraft yaws in the direction of the failed engine. YAWING MOMENT The yawing moment is the product of thrust from the operating engine multiplied by the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm), plus the drag from the failed engine multiplied by the distance between the engine centre line and the CG. The strength of the yawing moment will depend on: - how much thrust the operating engine is developing (throttle setting and density altitude). - the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm). - how much drag is being produced by the failed engine. The rudder moment, which balances the yawing moment, is the result of the rudder force multiplied by the distance between the fin CP and the CG (rudder arm) The ability of the pilot to counteract the yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust will depend on: - rudder displacement (affecting rudder force). - CG position (affecting rudder arm). - the IAS (affecting rudder force). Rudder to Stop Yaw - Bank Towards Live Engine It is more aerodynamically efficient to balance the rudder sideforce by banking towards the live engine, so that lift gives a sideways component opposite to the rudder force. The angle of bank must not exceed 5°, to prevent excessive loss of vertical lift component. Banking towards the live engine also reduces the side force on the fin from sideslip, which minimizes VMC, effectively reduces the yawing moment and gives more rudder authority to stop the yaw. The cockpit indication will be the turn needle central with the slip indicator (ball) one half diameter displaced towards the live engine. The ‘ball’ is not centred, but the aircraft is not sideslipping. This method produces minimum drag and gives the best ability to climb and is therefore the preferred method of putting the aircraft in equilibrium following engine failure.

options.C: Right crosswind, left engine failure.

key_points: For a propeller aircraft the length of the thrust arm is determined by the asymmetric effect of the propeller

At a positive angle of attack and when viewed from the rear, the thrust line of a clockwise rotating propeller is displaced to the right of the engine centre line because the down going blade generates more thrust than the up going blade
Therefore, if both engines rotate clockwise, the right engine will have a longer thrust arm than the left engine
learning.explanation: For a propeller aircraft the length of the thrust arm is determined by the asymmetric effect of the propeller. At a positive angle of attack and when viewed from the rear, the thrust line of a clockwise rotating propeller is displaced to the right of the engine centre line because the down going blade generates more thrust than the up going blade. Therefore, if both engines rotate clockwise, the right engine will have a longer thrust arm than the left engine. Thus, if the left engine fails, the thrust of the right engine acts through a longer thrust arm and will give a bigger yawing moment. The critical engine is the engine, the failure of which would give the biggest yawing moment. Consequently, we can safely say that with clockwise rotating propellers, the critical engine is the left one. The aircraft has the natural tendency to swing its nose into the wind in response to a sideslip (left wind results in left yaw). This will add to the already existent tendency to yaw towards the left due to the left engine failure and will increase the difficulty to control and the need for a larger rudder deflection. content.question: How does VMCL change with an increase of density altitude?

options.A: It increases due to the increased rudder force.
options.B: It decreases due to the decreased rudder force.
options.C: It increases due to the increased engine thrust.
options.D: It decreases due to the decreased engine thrust.

key_points: VMCL, the minimum control speed during approach and landing with all engines operating, is the calibrated airspeed at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the airplane with that engine still inoperative and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank of not more than 5°
VMCL is very similar to the other two minimum control speeds, in that it mainly is set by the thrust asymmetry vs the rudder force available
The asymmetry caused by running one engine at maximum power/thrust with the other engine failed/windmilling can be huge, and causes a very large yawing moment towards the dead engine
learning.explanation: VMCL, the minimum control speed during approach and landing with all engines operating, is the calibrated airspeed at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the airplane with that engine still inoperative and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank of not more than 5°. VMCL is very similar to the other two minimum control speeds, in that it mainly is set by the thrust asymmetry vs the rudder force available. The asymmetry caused by running one engine at maximum power/thrust with the other engine failed/windmilling can be huge, and causes a very large yawing moment towards the dead engine. This must be counteracted by the rudder force, to stop the aircraft becoming uncontrollable. At high speeds, this is fine, as the rudder has plenty of airflow over it and therefore can counteract the thrust asymmetry just fine, but at lower speeds, this is not the case. There is a speed, below which the rudder does not have the available force to counteract the thrust asymmetry of a failed engine at maximum thrust. This would be because the rudder does not have a fast enough airflow over it, and has reached its maximum deflection angle. Below this speed, even at maximum rudder deflection, the aircraft will yaw towards the dead engine. This speed is called the minimum control speed. Minimum control speeds change with the density altitude, but not because of the airflow over the rudder (this has a small effect), instead due to the difference in thrust available from the engine. At lower density altitudes (higher air densities), there is more air to be mixed with fuel and burnt, so the thrust is higher, and therefore the thrust asymmetry with a failed engine is higher, and the rudder needs more airflow to counteract this higher moment, so the minimum control speed is higher. Therefore, at an increased density altitude, the thrust is lower, so the VMCL is decreased also.

The total lift of a balanced turn provides the centripetal force and the force that opposes the mass of the airplane. If there is acceleration towards the center of the turn the airplane is slipping and if it is away from the center of the turn the airplane is skidding. An overbanked airplane will slip into the turn and requires an increase of speed or a reduction in bank angle to correct this condition. An underbanked airplane will skid out of the turn, which requires a decreased speed or an increased bank angle to correct this condition. These are indicated on the turn and slip indicator by the needle one-way and the ball the other. If one engine fails in flight, the remaining thrust forces are asymmetrically displaced and the aircraft yaws in the direction of the failed engine. learning.explanation: UNRELIABLE AIRSPEED A failure to promptly recognise and respond to erroneous flight instrument indications can result in loss of control. The most probable reason for erroneous airspeed and/or altitude information is an obstruction of the pitot and/or static probes. It is highly unlikely that the aircraft probes will be obstructed at the same time, to the same degree and in the same way. Abnormally large Mach number or IAS fluctuations, and differences between the indications at each pilot position, or between target and actual speed, may suggest an unreliable airspeed condition. Abnormal correlation between the basic flight parameters (pitch, thrust, airspeed, altitude, and vertical speed indications) allow the flight crew to suspect an erroneous speed/altitude indication: - The altitude does not increase, whereas there is an important nose-up pitch and high thrust - The IAS increases, whereas there is an important nose-up pitch - The IAS decreases, whereas there is an important nose-down pitch - The IAS decreases, whereas there is a nose-down pitch and the aircraft is descending. In the event of unreliable airspeed indications, a crew should fly the approximate pitch and thrust normally expected at that stage of flight until it is discovered which (if any) system is indicating correctly or the problem is resolved. Aircraft manufacturers issue appropriate guidance for specific aircraft types including pitch and thrust settings to fly at different stages of flight if airspeed information is not available. The pilots should use sources independent from the pitot static systems, capable of providing reliable information for situational awareness: - RPM (N1) for engine thrust indication - Attitude indicator - Stall warning - Ground speed and position information from Navigation systems.

learning.explanation: Consider an aircraft in a straight steady climb along a straight flight path inclined at an angle (γ) to the horizontal. γ (gamma) is the symbol used for climb angle. The forces on the aircraft consist of Lift, normal to the flight path; Thrust and Drag, parallel to it; and Weight, parallel to the force of gravity. Weight is resolved into two components: one opposite Lift (W cos γ) and the other acting in the same direction as Drag (W sin γ), backwards along the flight path. The requirements for equilibrium are: Thrust must equal the sum of Drag plus the backwards component of Weight; and Lift must equal its opposing component of Weight. For equilibrium at a greater angle of climb, the Lift required will be less, and the backwards component of Weight will be greater. L = W cosγ T = D + W sinγ In a straight steady climb, Lift is less than Weight because Lift only has to support a proportion of the weight, this proportion decreasing as the climb angle increases. The remaining proportion of Weight is supported by engine Thrust. It can be seen that for a straight steady climb the Thrust required is greater than Drag. This is to balance the backward component of Weight acting along the flight path. The climb gradient can be described as: sin γ = (T−D)/W For very shallow flight path angles (γ), we can assume that lift is approximately equal to Weight, therefore the climb gradient can be described as: sin γ = T/W−D/L In this exercise, Weight is equal to 670000 N, D/L ratio is equal to 1/9 and Thrust equal to 118000 N per engine. For the all engines (two) climb gradient and applying the formula defined above: sin γ = 236000/670000−1/9 sinγ = 0.241 ⇒ sinγ = 24.1% The climb gradient is 24.1%.

learning.explanation: In straight and level flight, an aircraft has 4 main forces acting on it. They create "force couples", in that Thrust cancels out Drag and Lift cancels out Weight. Unfortunately, it is not quite that simple, as, taking Lift vs Weight for instance, the two forces do not act through the same point. Weight acts through the CG, and Lift acts through the CP (Centre of Pressure), which is located behind the CG. This creates a nose-down moment (turning force) on the aircraft. There are a few ways to cancel out this moment, one we regularly see is low-mounted engines. This means that the thrust line will exist below the line of the drag, and will cause a small nose-up moment. That is not usually enough to cancel out the Lift vs Weight nose-down moment though, we need something else. Our horizontal stabiliser and elevators on the tail can be used to provide another vector of lift, but this time downwards. We often see horizontal stabilisers designed as "upside-down wings" to make them more efficient at producing downforce. This pushes the aircraft tail down, which creates a nose-up moment, big enough to even out the aircraft's pitch moments. Thankfully, we can modulate this by using variable incidence tailplanes and elevator trim to produce the right amount of downforce for stable flight. The downforce does act with our weight though, and means that our main wing has to produce even more lift to maintain level flight. The further forward the CG, the more downforce is required, and the greater lift. This is why aircraft are more efficient with an aft CG (within limits of course), as the less lift required means less induced drag. A forward movement of CG is therefore equivalent to an increase in mass on the stall speed (VS)

learning.explanation: In level flight, any turn will be coordinated or uncoordinated. A coordinated turn is one in which the only acceleration is along the normal axis of the airplane, towards the center of the turn, and the angle of bank is precisely correct for the aircraft speed and the radius of turn. If not all these factors are present, the turn will be uncoordinated and there will be a lateral acceleration either towards or away from the center of the turn. The total lift of a balanced turn provides the centripetal force and the force that opposes the mass of the airplane. If there is acceleration towards the center of the turn the airplane is slipping and if it is away from the center of the turn the airplane is skidding. Either condition will be indicated on the turn and slip indicator. An overbanked airplane will slip into the turn and requires an increase of speed or a reduction in bank angle to correct this condition. An underbanked airplane will skid out of the turn, which requires a decreased speed or an increased bank angle to correct this condition. These are indicated on the turn and slip indicator by the needle one-way and the ball the other. Most passenger transport airplanes are restricted to a maximum rate of turn of 3◦ per second, referred to as a rate one turn. To maintain altitude and airspeed when executing a turn both the angle of attack and the thrust have to be increased above their level flight values.

key_points: ENGINE FAILURE If one engine on a conventional twin-engine aircraft fails in flight, it adversely affects its performance and controllability

With both engines operating at the same power setting on a twin-engine aircraft, the amount of thrust produced by each engine is identical and their lines of action are symmetrically displaced about the aircraft's normal axis
If one engine fails in flight, the remaining thrust forces are asymmetrically displaced and the aircraft yaws in the direction of the failed engine
learning.explanation: ENGINE FAILURE If one engine on a conventional twin-engine aircraft fails in flight, it adversely affects its performance and controllability. With both engines operating at the same power setting on a twin-engine aircraft, the amount of thrust produced by each engine is identical and their lines of action are symmetrically displaced about the aircraft's normal axis. If one engine fails in flight, the remaining thrust forces are asymmetrically displaced and the aircraft yaws in the direction of the failed engine. YAWING MOMENT The yawing moment is the product of thrust from the operating engine multiplied by the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm), plus the drag from the failed engine multiplied by the distance between the engine centre line and the CG. The strength of the yawing moment will depend on: - how much thrust the operating engine is developing (throttle setting and density altitude). - the distance between the thrust line and the CG (thrust arm). - how much drag is being produced by the failed engine. The rudder moment, which balances the yawing moment, is the result of the rudder force multiplied by the distance between the fin CP and the CG (rudder arm) The ability of the pilot to counteract the yawing moment due to asymmetric thrust will depend on: - rudder displacement (affecting rudder force). - CG position (affecting rudder arm). - the IAS (affecting rudder force).

content.question: While briefing for an IFR approach, the pilot notices a maximum speed requirement on the reversal procedure. Exceeding the defined maximum speed might be hazardous, because he/she might NOT be able to comply with the required (1) _____, due to exceeding the expected (2) _____.

options.A: (1) bank angle; (2) rate of turn
options.B: (1) limits of the protected areas; (2) rate of turn
options.C: (1) limits of the protected areas; (2) radius of turn

learning.explanation: 081.08.01.05.12: Explain situations in which turn radius is relevant for safety, such as maximum speed limits on departure or arrival plates, or outbound speed categories on approach plates, and the implications/hazards of exceeding given speeds. Turn radius is dependent on airspeed and bank angle only. However, during normal airline operations, bank angle is limited (normally to 30º) to ensure a coordinated turn with the average piloting skills. As bank angle is maximized, turn radius is a function of speed only. Therefore, should any arrival or approach area be limited by, for example, airspace structure or terrain, speed must also be limited. Alternative Explanation: ICAO Doc 8168 1.3.8 The instrument approach chart (IAC) will specify the individual categories of aircraft for which the procedure is approved. Normally, procedures will be designed to provide protected airspace and obstacle clearance for aircraft up to and including Category D. However, where airspace requirements are critical, procedures may be restricted to lower speed categories. 1.3.9 Alternatively, the procedure may specify a maximum IAS for a particular segment without reference to aircraft category. In any case, it is essential that pilots comply with the procedures and information depicted on instrument flight charts and the appropriate flight parameters shown in Tables I-4-1-1 and I-4-1-2 if the aircraft is to remain in the areas developed for obstacle clearance purposes. To stay within limits of the protected area, the radius of turn has to be restricted in order to control the physical flight path. The rate of turn implies the rate of change of heading. A certain rate of change of heading can be achieved by either modifying the TAS or the radius of turn (Rate of turn = TAS/radius of turn). Therefore, specifying a certain rate of turn alone does not guarantee the physical flight path will stay in the protected area (e.g. To stay below a certain rate of turn, the radius of turn can be increased at a constant TAS).
